El Banco Comunal María Auxiliadora se reúne en La parroquia Sequita que pertenece a Montecristi prospero cantón manabita, lleno de gente trabajadora, dedicada y orgullosa de sus raíces, La Sequita es una parroquia donde sus habitantes son gente honesta que solo saben trabajar y dedicarse a sus familias.

En este lugar vive la señora Elena, tiene 61 años de edad, mantiene una relación de unión libre de la cual tiene 7 hijos todos mayores de edad, tres de ellos viven con ella los mismos que junto a su esposo trabajan en el campo.

Nuestra amiga tiene una pequeña granja de pollos en su casa, compra por cajas los pollos cuando están pequeños y los cría por tres meses, luego los vende en pie o por libras a los vecinos o entrega a las tiendas de la localidad, dice que sus pollos se venden mucho ya que los cría con maíz por lo cual su carne es  parecida al pollo criollo. Trabaja todos los días de dos a tres horas por día. Su esposo también tiene sembríos de maíz y maní lo cual está en plena recolección.

Este crédito lo va a emplear en comprar más pollos, alimentos para estos y para pagar mano de obra para la recolección de la cosecha. Es socia fundadora del Banco Comunal y le gusta por la ayuda que le dan con los créditos. 

Su sueño es tener una granja grande y con tecnología.
texts.en:
The “Mary the Helper” Communal Bank meets in La Sequita parish, Manabita Canton, which is part of Montecristi. The canton is full of hard-working dedicated people who are proud of their roots. La Sequita is a parish with gentle, honest inhabitants who only know how to work and dedicate themselves to their families.

Elena, 61 years old, lives there in a free union which has produced 7 children, all adults now; and 3 still live with her and work alongside her husband in the countryside.

Our friend Elena operates a small chicken farm at her house. She buys cartons of young baby chicks and raises them for 3 months, then sells them on foot or by the pound to neighbors, or delivers them to local stores. Elena says her chickens sell well, because she raises them on corn, which makes their meat similar to that of creole chickens.  Elena works every day for 2 or 3 hours. Her husband also has farm plots planted in corn and peanuts, which are now being harvested.

This loan will be used to buy more chickens and feed for them, and to pay workers for harvesting the crop. Elena is a founding member of this communal bank and she likes it for the help it offers with the loans. 

Elena's dream is to have a large farm with modern technology.

loans.use: to buy chickens and chicken feed, and to pay workers.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To build a workshop

loans.name: Olaya Georgina

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal María Auxiliadora se reúne en La parroquia Sequita que pertenece a Montecristi prospero cantón manabita, lleno de gente trabajadora, dedicada y orgullosa de sus raíces, La Sequita es una parroquia donde sus habitantes son gente honesta que solo saben trabajar y dedicarse a sus familias.

En este lugar conocimos a la señora Olaya, tiene 40 años de edad, es madre soltera de  tres hijos de 23, 19 y 17 años de edad, el menor de ellos estudia en colegio  y es el quien aun vive en su casa.
 
Nuestra amiga tiene una tienda en su casa, allí  vende toda clase de víveres, pero también vende productos de Yanbal (productos de belleza, cosméticos, perfumería y accesorios para damas), productos que vende en su casa y también sale a recorrer,  trabaja todos los días desde las 6h00 hasta las 20h00, su  hijo le ayuda en su negocio cuando está desocupado y en los momentos que ella sale a vender y cobrar sus productos ya que ella deja a crédito y cobra por semanas,  lleva más de 2 años con su tienda y con sus productos de Yanbal mucho más tiempo, es así que ella ha podido sacar adelante a sus hijos.

Este crédito lo va emplear en comprar víveres y cosméticos de Yanbal para surtir su negocio. Está desde el inicio en el Banco Comunal, está en la directiva del mismo y le gusta porque el grupo es muy ordenado y cumplido.
 
Su sueño es seguir adelante.
texts.en:
The communal bank "María Auxiliadora" meets in La Sequita parish, which is in the Montecristi region and the canton of Manabita.  This is a place full of hardworking people who are proud of their roots.  La Sequita is a parish where the inhabitants are honest people who are dedicated to their work and their families.  

Here we meet Olaya, who is 40 years old.  She is the single mother of three children, aged 23, 19 and 17.  The youngest of these attends school, and he still lives in her house.

Our friend Olaya has a store in her house where she sells all types of groceries.  She also sells Yanbal products (beauty products, cosmetics, perfumes and women's accessories) from her house, and she takes her products out around to sell.  She works every day from 6am until 8pm.  Her son helps her with the business when he's not busy, and in those times when she goes out to sell and to collect.  She sells her products on credit, and collects on a weekly basis.  She has had this store for more than 2 years, and she's been selling Yanbal products for much longer.  In this way, she has been able to get ahead with her children.

She will use this loan to buy groceries and Yanbal cosmetics to stock her store.  She has been with her communal bank from the start, and she is on the board.  She likes it because the group is very organized and accomplished.

Her dream is to continue to move ahead.

loans.use: to buy groceries and Yanbal cosmetics

loans.name: Aneela's Group

texts.en:
Aneela has requested a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband’s business who is involved in brick sales. He purchases bricks from different dealers and sells to the required customers. He is well-known for his business. He has been in this business for over 8 years. With the loan investment, he will buy bricks in larger quantity for reselling. 

Aneela herself is a very creative and talented lady. She not only gives required time to her household works, but also manages her sewing business very well. From the earnings, she runs the financial expenses with her husband. 

Aneela hopes that with this investment, her husband’s business will continue to prosper so that he can offer an even better service to his customers.

loans.use: To buy bricks for selling

loans.name: Las Florecitas Group

texts.es: Este grupo solidario se llama Las Florecitas está conformado por la señora Rosalia va a comprar con su préstamo verduras, carnes, chiles, ajonjolí, almendras, ajos, semillas, la señora Rosa va a comprar zapatos de dama,  caballero y niños, compra de maíz, carne, chiles, manteca, queso, requeson, la señora Maria va a comprar huevo, papel higiénico, aceite, azucar, jabon, refresco, la señora Alberta va a comprar maíz,  la señora Clara va a comprar productos nutricionales por paquete. La señora Maria tiene 76 años de edad, ella es viuda, ella tiene 5 hijos 4 mujeres y un varón todos mayores de edad ya casados. Ella solicito su préstamo para comprar refrescos, huevo, cloro, aceite, café, norzuiza, sopas, azúcar etc. parra surtir su tienda de abarrotes, ella inicio su negocio hace 30 años la necesidad la hiso que iniciara su negocio tenía que mantener a sus hijos, su negocio es importante porque tiene ingresos para la comida, a ella le gusta trabajar a así tiene ingresos del diario, ella utiliza las ganancias para pagar la luz que le llega muy cara. Sus sueños y esperanza son que Dios le permita vivir para seguir trabajando y que sus hijos estén bien lo mejor para ellos, que vivan contentos como hermanos. Ella esto feliz con el préstamo que va a recibir va a surtir su tienda  ya que en ella sus clientes encuentran de todo cominos, clavos, pimienta, carbonato, ajos, chiles, tomates, cebolla y mucho mas y así ofrece a sus mejor servicio.  Las integrantes del grupo quieren decirle a Kiva y a Fundación Realidad “les damos las gracias que nos están ayudando con sus préstamos, nos cobran menos interés y que nos sigan apoyado con sus préstamos para salir adelante con los negocios y con las familias”.
texts.en:
This mutually supportive group, called Las Florecitas (The Little Flowers), is made up of: 
Señora Rosalia, who will use the loan to buy vegetables, meats, chillies, sesame, almonds, garlic, and seed.
Señora Rosa, who will buy shoes for women, men and children, and to buy corn, meat, chillies, lard, cheese, and ricotta.
Señora Maria, who will buy eggs, toilet paper, oil, sugar, ham, and soda.
Señora Alberta, who will buy corn.
Señora Clara, who will buy packages of nutritional products.

Señora Maria is 76 years old, is widowed, and has five children; four women and one man, all of whom are adults and already married.  She asks for the loan to buy sodas, eggs, bleach, oil, coffee, bouillon, soups, sugar, etc. in order to stock up her grocery store.  She began her business 30 years ago.  The reason she needed to start the business was because she had to care for her children.  Her business is important because she has income for food.  She likes to work so that she has daily income; she uses the earnings to pay for lighting which is very expensive.  Her dreams and hopes are that God allows her to live to continue working and that her children are well, do what is best for them, and live happily like brothers.  She is happy with the loan that she is going to receive to stock up her store so that her customers can find cumin, clove, pepper, bicarbonate, garlic, chillies, tomatoes, onions, and a lot more - thus offering them better service.  

The members of the group want to say to Kiva and Fundación Realidad, "we thank you for helping us with the loans, charging us little interest, and continuing to support us with the loans in order to get ahead with the businesses and with our families".

loans.use: to buy soda, eggs, bleach, oil, coffee, bouillon, soups, sugar, bread, ham, chocolate, firewood, corn, etc.

loans.name: Marilú Elizabeth

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal María Auxiliadora se reúne en La parroquia Sequita que pertenece a Montecristi prospero cantón manabita, lleno de gente trabajadora, dedicada y orgullosa de sus raíces, La Sequita es una parroquia donde sus habitantes son gente honesta que solo saben trabajar y dedicarse a sus familias.

En este lugar conocimos a la señora Marilú, tiene 41 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tienen cuatro hijos, tres de ellos ya  mayores de edad y uno de 11 años que estudia en colegio y es el que  aun vive con ella. Su esposo trabaja en una fábrica en Manta.

Nuestra amiga tiene una tienda en su casa, nos cuenta que con esto ella puede ayudar en algo en los gastos del hogar y también para los estudios de su hijo, su negocio aunque es pequeño lo tiene bien surtido de víveres, trabaja todos los días desde las 6h00 hasta las 18h00, dice que le gusta su negocio ya que allí se entretiene y a la vez se gana algo para el bienestar de su familia. Ella lleva más de 5 años y poco a poco con la ayuda de los créditos lo ha ido aumentando.

Este crédito lo va emplear en comprar arroz, azúcar, aceites  entre otros víveres para surtir su negocio. Está en el Banco Comunal hace más de 5  años y le gusta porque gracias a la ayuda de los créditos empezó su negocio. 

Su meta es darle lo mejor a su hijo.
texts.en:
The Community Bank María Auxiliadora meets in the Sequita parish, which belongs to the city of Montecristi and the village of Manabita, a community that is full or hardworking people who are dedicated to and proud of their roots and heritage. Sequita is a parish of honest people who work hard and are dedicated to their families.

Marilú is 41 years old and is married with four children, three of whom are grown and the youngest of whom is 11 years old. Their youngest child is in high school and still lives with his parents. Her husband works in a factory in Manta.

Marilú operates a store from her home, and this business allows her to help out with household expenses and with their son’s school expenses. Her business is small, but is well stocked with food items. She works every day from 6:00 am until 6:00 pm, and likes having her own business, since it keeps her busy and entertained, and also helps her generate income for the benefit of her family. She has been working at her store for more than five years, and little by little, with help from loans, she has grown her business.

She plans to use the support from this loan to purchase rice, sugar, oil and other food items to stock her business. She has been a member of the Community Bank for more than five years, and she enjoys being a member. Thanks to the support from the loans, she was able to start and maintain her business.

Her goal is to provide everything she can for her son.

loans.use: to purchase rice, sugar, oil and other food products.

loans.name: Mlongo

texts.en:
Mlongo is a mother of four children and is married to her husband Ngome. All of her children are enrolled in school. For the past year, she has been operating a café and selling to the neighborhood and passersby. She aims at expanding this business and venturing into outside catering in the future.

Mlongo owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. She describes high market competition to be her major challenge. She spends more on food and school fees over the month.

The requested loan of 20,000 Kenya shillings (KES) will be used to purchase rice, beans, and wheat flour, and to repair the premises,

loans.use: to purchase rice, beans, and wheat flour, and repair the premises.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine is 41 years old and lives in Sebac, Tudela. She is married with 3 children. 

Josephine has a general store that sells a variety of products. She has had this business for 6 years. Josephine requested a loan of 10,000 PHP to purchase additional products such as canned goods, noodles, beverages, detergents, etc.. Josephine has been a member of PMPC for 7 years. In the future, Josephine hopes to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional products such as canned goods, noodles, beverages, detergents, etc.

loans.name: Rolando

texts.en: Rolando is from the village of Disimuray. He is 47 years old, married, and has four children. To make a living,  Rolando owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting corn for sale. He has been engaged in his business for 15 years and earns approximately 40,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) every crop season. Now, Rolando is requesting a loan of 50,000 PHP which will be used to purchase seedlings and fertilizer for his farm business. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the business.

loans.use: to purchase seedlings and fertilizer for his farm

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en: Mariam is a 30-year-old married woman who has 5 school-going children. She has rented a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. For the past 4 years, she has been selling charcoal from home, selling to the neighbors and passersby. Mariam’s goal is to open a charcoal depot in the future. High transport cost to her place of operation poses a challenge to her. She depends only on this business for her livelihood. She has requested a loan of 25,000 KES to add stock of charcoal for sale.

loans.use: to add stock of charcoal for sale.

loans.name: Concepcion

texts.es:
La señora Concepcion, se caracteriza por ser una persona amable, cordial  y sobre todo muy humilde.
Es originaria de una ciudad de Oaxaca donde hay un río llamado Río Verde en los limites con un pueblo  vecino llamado San Pedro Tututepec.
Doña Concepcion tiene treinta y siete años de edad, está felizmente casada con el señor Crecenciano con quien tiene tres hijos Luis Felipe, Daniela y Ana Karen.
Dice que se dedica a la venta de refacciones automotrices desde hace  un año seis meses y cuenta con un local en  la colonia centro de su comunidad donde empezó vendiendo accesorios para carros y con las ganancias obtenidas fue que decidió vender refacciones ya que sus clientes se lo recomendaban.
Su esposo le ayuda en la refaccionaria los fines de semana ya que atiende su taller de hojalatería y pintura.
Uno de los sueños que tenia sin cumplir es tener su local propio ya que donde tiene su refaccionaria es rentado pero el crédito le va ayudar a poner una cortina en el local que su esposo construyó donde tiene su taller de hojalatería.
Una de las cosas lindas de su trabajo es que con el tiempo ha podido aprender qué es lo que llevan los carros y sobre todo cómo ayudar a sus clientes cuando tienen duda acerca de las piezas que necesitan.
Ella pidió el préstamo para la compra de más refacciones y para comprar una cortina para su local.
Le da las gracias a Vision Fund por ayudarla a que sus sueños se cumplan y no se queden truncados.
texts.en:
Concepcion is known for being friendly, warm, and most of all, modest. She is originally from a town in Oaxaca where the Rio Verde divides her town and the neighboring San Pedro Tututepec. Concepcion is 37 years old and is happily married to Crecenciano and they have three children together; Luis Felipe, Daniela and Ana Karen. 
She tells us that she has been selling automotive spare parts for about a year and a half now and she has a small site in the colonial center in her community where she began selling car accessories and with the earnings she decided to sell spare parts because her customers recommended it. 
Her husband helps her on weekends because he otherwise tends to his body work and paint shop. 
One of her dreams she hopes to achieve is to have her own store because where she currently sells her automotive parts is rented, but the credit will help her put up a curtain in the store her husband has made where he has his workshop.
One of the beautiful things about her work is that she has been able to learn about cars and their parts and also how to help her customers when they are unsure of what parts they need. She is asking for a loan to purchase more automotive parts and to purchase a curtain for her store. She thanks Vision Fund for helping her fulfill her dreams that would otherwise be cut short.

loans.use: purchase more automotive parts and to purchase a curtain for her store

loans.name: La Buchicata Group

texts.es:
En este grupo se integró una nueva persona es la señora Gladis Alicia quien se dedica a la venta de comida.
La representante de este grupo es la señora María de la Paz, una señora alegre amable, trabajadora y sobre todo muy  humilde.
Doña Mari como mejor la conocen nos dice que se dedica a la venta de pan, queso, carne enchilada, pollo destazado y huevos de granja desde hace diez años. Nos dice que lo que más le gusta de su negocio es atender a las personas y regalarles una sonrisa y alegrarles la vida. Doña Mari cuenta que anteriormente vendía mercancía de abarrotes pero por cuestiones de salud tuvo que salir de la ciudad y cerró su tienda de abarrotes, pero cuando regreso empezó a vender  huevos, carne enchilada y queso; con las ganancias compró pollo para la venta. Ella vende los pollos en su casa: saca una mesa en el corredor y se sienta a vender.
Pidió el crédito para la compra de más pollos para la venta ya que considera que es un buen negocio, también lo va invertir para la compra de mercancía de abarrotes ya que desea abrir su tienda una vez más.
Le da las gracias a fundacion por el apoyo que les da a todas las mujeres trabajadoras y humildes.
texts.en:
Gladis Alicia, who makes a living selling food, is a new person who became part of this group.

This group's representative is María de la Paz, a happy, nice, hardworking, and above all, very humble, woman. Ms. Mari, as she is better known, tells us that she has been making a living selling bread, cheese, meat enchiladas, butchered chicken, and farm eggs for ten years. She tells us that what she likes most about her business is attending to people and giving them the gift of a smile to make their lives happier. Ms. Mari says that formerly she used to sell grocery merchandise but for health reasons had to leave the city and close her grocery shop. When she returned she began to sell eggs, meat enchiladas, and cheese. With her earnings she bought a chicken to sell. She sells chicken in her home: she takes a table out in the corridor and sits down to sell.

She asked for a loan to buy more chicken to sell since she considers it to be a good business. Also, she's going to invest it in the purchase of grocery merchandise since she would like to open her store again.

She is thankful for the foundation for the support they give to all the hardworking, humble women.

loans.use: to buy chicken and grocery merchandise to sell.

loans.name: Sini Titi San Andrés Group

texts.es:
Este grupo se llama Sini Titi San Andrés, está conformado por ocho personas indígenas, originarias de un pequeño pueblo llamado San Andrés Huaxpaltepec, Oaxaca, es un pueblo lleno de danzas y tradiciones. Una de las danzas típicas es la de las mascaritas, que se baila en carnaval, acompañada de orquesta y recrea algunos aspectos de la vida de nuestros pueblos.

El señor Damián de treinta y cuatro años de edad es el representante del grupo, él se dedica a la venta de hierbas curativas, también cura a las personas de espanto, fiebre y a los niños los cura de coraje. Las personas de pueblos vecinos y de la comunidad van a su casa para recibir su ayuda limipiándolos con albahaca y huevos. También lleva vendiendo hierbas curativas desde hace quince años, y su mamá fue quien le enseñó todo sobre esta práctica ya que ella quedó viuda y a través de dicha actividad los mantenía a él y a sus hermanos.
Damián menciona que con la ayuda de Vision Fund ha podido seguir con su negocio, y él se siente satisfecho ya que con su trabajo cura a las personas para que se sientan sanos. Con la ayuda del préstamo va a comprar más hierbas curativas para su venta.

Las otras integrantes del grupo son:
Teofila- se dedica a la venta de antojitos mexicanos.
Yesenia- se dedica a la venta de bisutería.
Bianca-se dedica a la venta de ropa.
Nelida- se dedica a la venta de antojitos mexicanos.
Margarita- se dedica a la venta de hierbas curativas.
Maria- se dedica a la venta de antojitos mexicanos.
Vianney- se dedica a la venta de antojitos mexicanos.

Todos ellos le dan las gracias a Kiva y Vision Fund por ayudar a las personas trabajadoras que desean sobresalir y cumplir sus metas.
texts.en:
This group is called Sini Titi San Andrés and is made up of eight indigenous people who are from a small town named San Andrés Huaxpaltepec, Oaxaca.  It is a town full of dances and traditions.  One of the typical dances is "las mascaritas" (the little masks), which they dance during the carnival, accompanied by the orchestra and it portrays some aspects of the life in their small towns.  

Damián, who is thirty four years old, is the group's representative.  He works selling medicinal herbs and he also cures people of fever, "espanto" (a sickness brought on by a great fright), and he cures children of anxiety.  People from neighboring towns and from the community go to his home to receive his care and he cleans them with basil and eggs.  He also has sold medicinal herbs for fifteen years.  His mother was the one who taught him everything about this practice since she became a widow and it was through this means that she provided for him and his brothers.

Damián mentions that with the help of Vision Fund, he has been able to continue his business and he feels satisfied since with his work, he cures people so that they feel healthy.  With the help of the loan, he's going to buy more medicinal herbs for his sale. 

The other group members are:
Teofila - sells Mexican snacks
Yesenia - sells jewelry
Bianca - sells clothing
Nelida- sells Mexican snacks
Margarita - sells medicinal herbs
Maria - sells Mexican snacks
Vianney- sells Mexican snacks

All of them give thanks to Kiva and Vision Fund for helping hard-working people who want to succeed and achieve their goals.

loans.use: to purchase medicinal herbs to sell.

loans.name: Las Margaritas 2 Group

texts.es:
La señora Domitila es una persona muy responsable y trabajadora, cuenta con 49 años de edad está casada con el señor Gregorio que es albañil y se dedica al campo también, tiene 3 hijos Never tiene 25 años y Gregorio tiene 20 años ellos dos le ayudan a su papá y su hija Adilene tiene 22 y ella le ayuda a su mamá ninguno estudia.
Domitila es comerciante y se dedica a la venta del pan pues se los entregan cada tercer día en la semana que son los lunes, miércoles y viernes como no tienen un local por ejemplo para vender tienen que salirse a andar vendiendo por las casas pero aun así dice que si vende bien pues su hija se va por un lado y ella se va por otro ella cree que le va mejor así, que tener su propio horno para hacer el pan.
Domitila es integrante del grupo Las Margaritas 2 el cual está integrado por 12 mujeres muy trabajadoras que son capaces de salir adelante por sus familias, a continuación serán mencionadas y cada una de las actividades que realizan: Bertha vende ropa, Domitila vende pan, Marcela vende comida, Isabel vende perfumes, Magally vende pizza, Divina vende ropa, Monica vende comida, Eulalia vende tacos, Maximina vende refrescos, Herminia vende frutas y verduras, Maria de los Angeles vendes verduras, Ignacia vende perfumes.
texts.en:
Domitila is a responsible and hardworking person who is 49 years old and is married to Gregorio, who works in construction and also in agriculture.  They have 3 children. Never, 25, and Gregorio, 20, both help their father, and her daughter Adilene, 22, helps her mother.  None of them are in school.

Domitila is a trader and she works selling bread which she delivers every other day of the week: Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays.  As she doesn't have a store, in order to sell she has to go out selling door-to-door.  However, she says that if her sales are good, she goes out to sell in one part of town and her daughter sells in another.  She believes that she does better this way than if she had her own oven to make the bread.

Domitila is a member of the communal bank "Las Margaritas 2," which is made up of 12 very hardworking women who are capable of getting ahead for their families.  They are mentioned below, along with their type of business.  Bertha sells clothing, Domitila sells bread, Marcela sells food, Isabel sell perfumes, Magally sells pizza, Divina sells clothing, Monica sells food, Eulalia sells tacos, Maximina sells soft drinks, Herminia sells fruits and vegetables, Maria de los Angeles sells vegetables, and Ignacia sells perfumes.

loans.use: to buy bags, brown wrapping paper, baskets and other items

loans.name: Flor Mechoacan Group

texts.es:
Este grupo se llama Flor Mechoacan está conformado por dieciséis personas trabajadoras y humildes, originarios de Santa Catarina Mechoacan; una de las tradiciones de este pueblo es la fiesta patronal que se celebra el 24 de noviembre, fiesta de honor a Santa Catarina, con bailes, juegos pirotécnicos, misas y procesiones.
Una de las integrantes del grupo es la señora Patricia de veintiocho años de edad, se caracteriza por ser una señora amable trabajadora e indígena con deseos de superación. Dice que se dedica a la venta  tacos de cecina, chorizo y carne enchilada desde hace ocho años. Su taquería se encuentra en el sitio de taxis de su comunidad, obtuvo su negocio vendiendo tacos dorados en las calles, pero con sus ganancias pudo comprar  bancos y mesas,  y uno de sus hermanos le prestó su casa para poner el establecimiento y pudiera atender mejor a sus clientes.
Esta felizmente casada con el señor Abel quien le ayuda a atender su taqueria, tiene dos hijos Abel Andrés de nueve años de edad y Fátima Yoselin de seis años de edad. Patricia abre su negocio a las cuatro de la tarde por que en las mañanas atiende a sus hijos y los lleva a la escuela; cierra su taquería a las nueve de la noche. Además también se dedica a la elaboración de servilletas. Pidió el crédito para la compra de más ingredientes para la elaboración de  tacos como es tortillas, carne de res, carne enchilada, chorizó, aceite y verduras. Le da las gracias a fundacion por ayudar a todas las personas indígenas.

Las otras integrantes del grupo son:

Crescencia- se dedica a la venta de antojitos mexicanos.
Rosa- se dedica a la venta de antojitos mexicanos.
Concepcion- se dedica a la venta antojitos mexicanos.
Agustin Olivero –se dedica a la venta de antojitos mexicanos.
Catalina Sofia- se dedica a la venta de antojitos mexicanos.
Heliodora- se dedica a la venta  de servilletas.
Silvia – se dedica a la venta de servilletas.
Luisa Clementina- se dedica a la venta de mercancía  de abarrotes.
Sinforosa Natalia- se dedica a la venta de antojitos mexicanos.
Hilda- se dedica a la venta de antojitos mexicanos.
Margarita- se dedica a la venta de antojitos mexicanos.
Mirna- se dedica a la venta de antojitos mexicanos.
Felicita- se dedica a la venta de servilletas.
Catalina- se dedica a la venta de comida.
Macrina- se dedica a la venta de antojitos mexicanos.
Le dan las gracias a fundacion por el apoyo que les da a todas las mujeres trabajadoras.
texts.en:
The group known as Flor Mechoacan is made up of 16 hardworking and humble people from the town of Santa Catarina Mechoacan. One of the traditions in this town is the festival of the patron saint which is celebrated on November 24th, in honor of Santa Catarina, with dances, games, fireworks, masses and processionals.

One of the members of the group is Patricia, 28, who is known as a friendly, hardworking woman of indigenous descent who wants to better herself. For 8 years she has been selling tacos made with cured meat, sausage, and chili meat. Her taqueria is at the taxi stand in her community. She started her business selling fried tacos in the street, but with her earnings she was able to buy benches and tables and one of her siblings lent her his house to put in a restaurant so she could better attend her customers. 

She is happily married to Abel who helps out at the taqueria. They have two children: Abel Andres, 9, and Fatima Yoselin, 6. Patricia opens her business at four in the afternoon because in the morning she takes care of her children and takes them to school. She closes the taqueria at 9pm. She also makes napkins. She asked for a loan to buy more ingredients for her tacos like tortillas, beef, ground beef, sausage, oil and vegetables. She thanks the foundation for helping out indigenous peoples. 

The other members of the group are:

Crescencia-  she sells Mexican snacks
Rosa- sells Mexican snacks
Concepcion- sells Mexican snacks
Agustin Olivero – sells Mexican snacks
Catalina Sofia- sells Mexican snacks
Heliodora- sells napkins
Silvia – sells napkins
Luisa Clementina- sells groceries
Sinforosa Natalia- sells Mexican snacks
Hilda- sells Mexican snacks
Margarita- sells Mexican snacks
Mirna- sells Mexican snacks
Felicita- sells napkins
Catalina- sells food
Macrina- sells Mexican snacks

They are grateful to the foundation for the support that it has given all of these hardworking women.

loans.use: to buy ingredients to make tacos.

loans.name: Mary Jakeline

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal María Auxiliadora se reúne en La parroquia Sequita que pertenece a Montecristi prospero cantón manabita, lleno de gente trabajadora, dedicada y orgullosa de sus raíces, La Sequita es una parroquia donde sus habitantes son gente honesta que solo saben trabajar y dedicarse a sus familias.

En este lugar conocimos a la señora Mary, tiene 35 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tienen tres hijos de 12, 9 y 8 años de edad, el mayor estudian en colegio y los menores en escuela. Su esposo trabaja en la construcción.

Nuestra amiga para poder ayudar en algo a su esposo con los gastos del hogar y al ver que su marido no gana lo suficiente solicito uno de los créditos con el cual adecuo un pequeño local en su casa en el mismo que surtió una pequeña tienda de víveres, la misma que recién la tiene por un año pero que a pesar de tener tan poco tiempo le da buenas ganancias y satisfacciones, trabaja todos los días desde las 6h00 hasta las 20h00 o hasta más tarde si alguien necesita algo pues no se le hace problema atenderlos a cualquier hora.

Este crédito lo va emplear en comprar arroz, azúcar, aceites  entre otros víveres para surtir su negocio. Está en el Banco Comunal hace más de 10  años y le gusta por la ayuda que le brindan los créditos.
 
Sus metas son seguir adelante en su negocio y su vida familiar.
texts.en:
The María Auxiliadora ("Our Lady of Help") communal bank meets in Sequita parish in Montecristi, a prosperous canton in Manabí province full of hard-working, dedicated people who are proud of their roots. La Sequita's people are honest and know only how to work and dedicate themselves to their families.

In this place we meet Mary, 35 years old. She is married, and from this relationship she has three children aged 8, 9, and 12. The oldest is in secondary school and the younger ones are in primary school. Her husband works in construction.

In order to help her husband in some way with the household expenses, and seeing that he did not earn enough, our friend applied for one of the loans. With it, she fitted out a small area in her house in which she stocked a small grocery store. She has had it for a year, but despite having had it for such a short time, it has given her good earnings and satisfaction. She works every day from 6:00 am until 8:00 pm or even later if someone needs something, since it isn't a problem for her to wait on them at any time.

She will use this loan to buy rice, sugar, and oils, among other groceries, in order to stock her business. She has been in the communal bank for more than 10 years, and she likes it because of the help the loans provide.

Her goals are to continue moving forward with her business and her family life.

loans.use: to purchase rice, sugar, and oils, among other groceries

loans.name: Kim's Group

texts.en:
Kim was born in 1969. She lives in Trung Thon village, Dong Anh commune. She has two children. She and her husband are farmers. Not only growing rice, but also she goes to small business. She is the leader of 4-member group loan of SEDA. She has participated with SEDA since 2006 and always pays her loan punctually. The last cycle, she borrowed 5,014.000 Vietnamdong (VND). In this cycle, she would like to borrow 7,194.000 VND to buy fruits to sell.
 
About other borrowers in her group:
Tat is 41 years old. She has two children. She wants to borrow 5,450.000 VND to buy pigs.
Hanh is 42 years old. She has two children. She would like to borrow 6,758.000 VND to buy more iron scrap.
Dan is 59 years old. She would like to borrow 6,322.000 VND to buy iron scrap to resell.

loans.use: to buy fruits to sell.
